description: From Middle English rocke, rokke (“rock formation”), from Old English *rocc (“rock”), as in Old English stānrocc (“high stone rock, peak, obelisk”), and also later from Anglo-Norman roque, (compare Modern French roc, roche, rocher), from Medieval Latin rocca (attested 767), of uncertain origin, sometimes said to be of Celtic (in particular, perhaps Gaulish) origin (compare Breton roc'h).

entries.meaning: (uncountable) The naturally occurring aggregate of solid mineral matter that constitutes a significant part of the earth's crust.
examples: The face of the cliff is solid rock.

entries.meaning: A mass of stone projecting out of the ground or water.
examples: The ship crashed on the rocks.

entries.meaning: (chiefly British) A boulder or large stone; or (US, Canada) a smaller stone; a pebble.
examples: Some fool has thrown a rock through my window.

entries.meaning: (geology) Any natural material with a distinctive composition of minerals.
(slang) A precious stone or gem, especially a diamond.
examples: Look at the size of that rock on her finger!

entries.meaning: A large hill or island having no vegetation.
examples: Pearl Rock near Cape Cod is so named because the morning sun makes it gleam like a pearl.

entries.meaning: (figuratively) Something that is strong, stable, and dependable; a person who provides security or support to another.
examples: Celeste Talbert: She is my rock, my right hand.

entries.meaning: A lump or cube of ice.
examples: I'll have a whisky on the rocks, please.

entries.meaning: (Britain, uncountable) A type of confectionery made from sugar in the shape of a stick, traditionally having some text running through its length.
examples: While we're in Brighton, let's get a stick of rock!

entries.meaning: (US, slang) A crystallized lump of crack cocaine.
examples: Synonyms: crack rock, candy

entries.meaning: (US, slang) An unintelligent person, especially one who repeats mistakes.
(South Africa, slang, derogatory) An Afrikaner.
(US poker slang) An extremely conservative player who is willing to play only the very strongest hands.
The striped bass.
The huss or rock salmon.
examples: We ordered rock and chips to take away.

entries.meaning: (US, basketball, slang) A basketball.
examples: Yo homie, pass the rock!

entries.meaning: (US, baseball, slang) A mistake.
examples: Now, you should never make the last out of an inning at third, and when a player does it, everyone knows he pulled a rock.

entries.meaning: (curling) Synonym of stone.
(rock paper scissors) A closed hand (a handshape resembling a rock), that beats scissors and loses to paper. It beats lizard and loses to Spock in rock-paper-scissors-lizard-Spock.
(informal, cricket) A cricket ball, especially a new one that has not been softened by use
(CB radio slang) A crystal used to control the radio frequency.
examples: It was easily possible to double the cost of a CB rig just by adding all of the "rocks" necessary to do the job.

description: From Middle English rokken, from Old English roccian, from Proto-West Germanic *rokkōn, from Proto-Germanic *rukkōną (compare obsolete Dutch rokken, Middle High German rocken (“to drag, jerk”), Modern German rücken (“to move, shift”), Icelandic rukka (“to yank”)), from Proto-Germanic *rugnōną, from Proto-Indo-European *h₃ruk-néh₂, from *h₃rewk-, *h₃runk- (compare Latin runcāre (“to weed”), Latvian rũķēt (“to toss, dig”)).

entries.meaning: An act of rocking; a rocking motion; a sway.

verbs.description: rock (third-person singular simple present rocks, present participle rocking, simple past and past participle rocked)

entries.meaning: (transitive and intransitive) To move gently back and forth.
examples: Rock the baby to sleep.
The empty swing rocked back and forth in the wind.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To cause to shake or sway violently.
examples: A rising earthquake rocked the ground.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To sway or tilt violently back and forth.
examples: The boat rocked at anchor.

entries.meaning: (transitive and intransitive, of ore etc.) To be washed and panned in a cradle or in a rocker.
examples: The ores had been rocked and laid out for inspection.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To disturb the emotional equilibrium of; to distress; to greatly impact (most often positively).
examples: Downing Street has been rocked by yet another sex scandal.
She rocked my world.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To do well or to be operating at high efficiency.
(intransitive, stative) to be cool.
examples: That band rocks!

entries.meaning: (slang, transitive, euphemistic) to make love to or have sex with.
(intransitive) To sway one's body as a stim.

verbs.description: rock (third-person singular simple present rocks, present participle rocking, simple past and past participle rocked)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To play, perform, or enjoy rock music, especially with a lot of skill or energy.
examples: Let's rock!

entries.meaning: (intransitive, slang) To be very favourable or skilful; excel; be fantastic.
examples: Synonym: rule
Antonyms: stink, suck
Chocolate rocks.
My holidays in Ibiza rocked! I can't wait to go back.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To thrill or excite, especially with rock music.
examples: Let's rock this joint!

entries.meaning: (transitive) To do something with excitement yet skillfully.
examples: I need to rock a piss.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To wear (a piece of clothing, outfit etc.) successfully or with style; to carry off (a particular look, style).
examples: Synonym: sport

description: From Middle English rok, rocke, rokke, perhaps from Middle Dutch rocke (whence Dutch rokken), Middle Low German rocken, or Old Norse rokkr (whence Icelandic / Faroese rokkur, Danish rok, Swedish spinnrock (“spinning wheel”)). Cognate with Old High German rocko (“distaff”).

entries.meaning: (countable) Distaff.
(uncountable) The flax or wool on a distaff.
Archaic form of roc (mythical bird)
